attachments.title: Women are leaving the tech industry in droves
attachments.text: Ana Redmond launched into a technology career for an exciting challenge and a chance to change the world. She was well-equipped to succeed too: An ambitious math and science wiz, she could code faster, with fewer errors, than anyone she knew.
attachments.fallback: latimes.com: Women are leaving the tech industry in droves

text: can the drones be honey powered? that would be awesome
<@U02E3CRMA>: the fastest to $1m was apparently a motorcycle helmet and it took them 45 hours.  That bee hive is going to hit $2m in 24

Can you imagine the adrenaline rush those two guys must be on right now.   They asked for $70k.   I'd probably be curled up in a ball rocking in the corner, oh shit, oh shit, oh shit, how do I...  ah...  oh shit.

<@U02618EV1> indeed, that bites. :disappointed: So many initiatives right now are about getting K-12 girls interested in tech/science, but the huge problem is mid-career women getting drummed out of a tech career path because of the constant, increasing level of stress from systemic sexism and microaggressions.
Yeah that's so sad
<@U02F8TTPU> That's a good point. Although there's still hope that when those K-12 girls enter the workforce en masse they could change it from within.
that was my hope when I went through my CS education and early career...
And also hope that smaller companies with much more progressive equality standards like Uncorked Studios flourish. :simple_smile:

<@U02F8TTPU>: Agreed. Saw so many great tech women leave mid-career either due to complete burnout, or being driven out by that kind of hostility. Here I am encouraging talented young engineers like my niece to get into tech, while at the same time not wanting to feed her to the wolves.
Yes!!
Exactly <@U0289USNA>
thanks for the donuts <@U0261PCRQ> !!!!
how hot do beehives get? are the exothermic?
i dont know but Dave is taking a beekeeping class soon so I can report back :simple_smile:
beehives to recharge batteries?

<@U02F8LF2X>: I think they produce little to no heat.  It's recommended to harvest honey in the afternoon as you want the ambient temperature to be enough to lower the viscosity so it pours out, otherwise it's too cool/viscous.  Of note though the hive is actually in the box underneath the honey-comb box.  Potentially the hive is a few degrees warmer.
